en.value: Talking about how and when you met your partner - Irregular verbs in the past simple
People talk about their relationships all the time. In this lesson, we're going to learn some simple ways of talking about a relationship and its different milestones.
When we say that two people make "a nice couple", we either mean that they look very good together, or that they have a good relationship. We can also say that two people are "good together".
Joe and Colette are really good together. They make such a nice couple.
How do you know each other? - We met at a book group.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
She dated him for a few months.
She [k]dated[/k] him for a few years.
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
Which verb do we use to describe when we see someone for the first time?

Some of the verbs we're using in this unit do not behave like regular verbs in the past simple tense. That's because they are irregular. See how many you can remember as you go along. We're going to look at these in more detail next.
We got together about a year ago.
They split up because he had an affair.
He's really upset because he broke up with his girlfriend.
Anita and Oliver [k]broke[/k] up last week!
"To split up" and "to break up" mean exactly the same thing. In British English, we tend to use "to split up" more when referring to married couples.
Are Lea and Dani still together? - No, they broke up.
Did you hear? Lucas and Laura split up!
Select the two words which mean the same as "split up".
Select the words in the correct order.
They got divorced two years ago.
There are a few different ways of using the words "marry" and "divorce", or different variants of them. Here are some other ways you might use them.
Match each sentence with its opposite.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Sevan and Holly are talking about the events of last night...
Billy and Sophia [k]broke up[/k] last night!
What!? No! That's so sad. They made such a nice [k]couple[/k].
Also did you know that Rachel and Brice [k]got together[/k]?
What about you? How was your night?
My night was good! I [k]met[/k] a girl and [k]got[/k] her number!
Good for you! So when are you getting [k]married[/k]!?

Not everyone's relationships are as turbulent as Sevan and Holly's friends'. It's hard to keep up with some people! In the following exercises, we're going to listen to sections of their dialogue and answer a few questions.
Listen to the audio. Select the most accurate statement.
Billy and Sophia had a good relationship.
Billy and Sophia were not together very long.
Billy and Sophia are boyfriend and girlfriend.
Rachel and Brice started a relationship.
Rachel and Brice broke up last night.
Rachel and Brice are getting married.
What does the word "got" mean in this context?
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
Match the beginning and end of each sentence.
Did you know Alyssa and Fisher [k]got[/k] [k]divorced[/k]?
She [k]dated[/k] him for a few years.
Type a similar expression to "to split up" in the correct tense.
Are any of your friends or relatives in a relationship? How did they meet their partner? Talk about where and when they met.
They got together ... / They make a nice ... / Unfortunately they ... up last ...
Irregular verbs in the past simple

Let's now take a look at some verbs that are irregular in the past simple tense. Irregular verbs have no standard ending, meaning that we have to learn each one individually. Have a look at the examples below.

In general, irregular verbs in the past simple do not change depending on the person in the sentence. However, the verb "to be" does change. Here's a recap of how to form the verb "to be" in the past simple.
Select the three verbs in the past simple.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Here are the past simple forms of some common irregular verbs:
This is the past simple form of the verb "to go".
This is the past simple form of the verb "to be".
Listen to the dialogue. Select the two irregular past simple verbs that you hear.
I [k]got a car when I was[/k] 23.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
Past simple of the verb to read

Imagine you are telling someone about your life or you are simply chatting with your colleagues about your weekend. In either case, you will need to link your ideas to sequence them. Read the short story below and pay attention to the words in bold.

Before I met my wife, I dated Carol. I was really upset when we split up. But after a while, we became good friends. Then, my wife and I got together around Christmas. We got married as soon as we finished university, and finally, we bought a house in Bristol.
We need these linkers to show the order in which events happen. They will help you to start, continue and finish your story. Have a look at some of them below.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Before I met my wife, I dated Carol.
When we split up, I was really upset.
[k]When[/k] we split up, she got really upset.
Mike and Emma got married while I was in Italy.
The connecting word "as" is similar in meaning to "while".
As I was walking home, I saw my old friend Ruby.
Match the beginning and the end of the phrase.
Select the word similar in meaning to "while".
[h]As[/h] I was getting off the train, my phone rang.
After I broke up with Sally, we became friends.
Then, Manuelle and Christelle came over.
To continue your story, you can also say "so".
So, after that, we never talked again.
After I broke up with Sally,
As soon as he finished school, he started a job.
Finally, after 10 years of marriage they got divorced.
They broke up in the end.
Select the answer you hear in the audio.
As soon as he got to London,
[k]Finally[/k], after 10 years of marriage, they got divorced .
[k]After[/k] months of looking, he [k]finally[/k] found a job.
Now let's have another look at all the words we've learned before we practise some more:
Select the word you hear in the audio.
[k]When[/k] they were in Crete, Maria and Mark got together.
Type the missing word into the gap.
[k]After|When|As soon as[/k] I broke up with Sally, we became friends.
[k]As I was[/k] getting off the train, my phone rang.
Select the words similar in meaning to "after".
Fill the gap with a phrase which is similar in meaning to "finally".
